Package dev.federicocapece.jdaze

Class Input

java.lang.Object
dev.federicocapece.jdaze.Input
public final class Input
extends java.lang.Object
 Input manager for the game engine

    Input()

    Get the mouse position as a Vector.

    Use this method inside the update() to check if a key is pressed and react to it.

    Use this method inside the update() to check if a key is NOT pressed and react to it.

    Use this method inside the update() to check if a mouse button is pressed and react to it.

  • Constructor Details

    • Input

      public Input()

  • Method Details

    • isKeyDown

      public static boolean isKeyDown​(int keyCode)
      Use this method inside the update() to check if a key is pressed and react to it.
      Parameters:
      keyCode - The keycode as integer, use the constants in: java.awt.KeyEvent
      Returns:
      true/false

    • isKeyUp

      public static boolean isKeyUp​(int keyCode)
      Use this method inside the update() to check if a key is NOT pressed and react to it. NOTE: this actually does !isKeyDown, so it is not recommended, just use !isKeyDown
      Parameters:
      keyCode - The keycode as integer, use the constants in: java.awt.KeyEvent
      Returns:
      true/false

    • getMouseWheelRotation

      public static float getMouseWheelRotation()
      Use this method inside the update() to check if the mouse wheel was rotated. This method will return a float: 
       positive = up
 negative = down
 zero     = no rotation
      NOTE: the rotation of the mouse wheel get reset after the update, so you shouldn't use it in combination with deltaTime.
      Returns:
      a float representing the mouseWheel rotation

    • isMouseDown

      public static boolean isMouseDown​(int buttonCode)
      Use this method inside the update() to check if a mouse button is pressed and react to it.
      Parameters:
      buttonCode - the MouseButton code as integer, use constants in: java.awt.MouseEvent
      Returns:

    • getMousePosition

      public Vector getMousePosition()
      Get the mouse position as a Vector. The mouse position is referred to the canvas, not to the world position. NOTE: You could theoretically store it inside your class and reuse it as it's directly updated by the Input Manager.
      Returns:
      the Vector representing the mouse position

    • getMouseWorldPosition

      public Vector getMouseWorldPosition()
      Get the mouse position inside the world coordinate system as a Vector. This is calculated every time you call it by using the Camera position, so it's recommended to store it and not to call this multiple time for every update.
      Returns:
      the Vector representing the mouse position
